articles.headline: Offshore Tax Breaks Lure Money Managers
articles.snippet: The rise of Caribbean tax havens coincides with recent calls by American legislators for greater oversight and taxation of hedge funds.
articles.abstract: The rise of Caribbean tax havens coincides with recent calls by American legislators for greater oversight and taxation of hedge funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILLIAM E. GRAYSON, the president of EGM Capital, a hedge fund firm in San Francisco, has never set foot on the Cayman Islands, but he knows that sun-baked Caribbean haven quite well. That’s because he set up one of his funds in the Caymans, where lucrative tax breaks and fabled financial secrecy have made this British territory a magnet for hedge fund managers.

articles.headline: Risk-Aversion Therapy on Wall St.
articles.snippet: Investors have some nerve to dump Blackstone’s shares — don’t they know who Steve Schwarzman is?
articles.abstract: Investors have some nerve to dump Blackstone’s shares — don’t they know who Steve Schwarzman is?
articles.lead_paragraph: THE bloom came off the Blackstone Group’s rose last week as the share price of this celebrated private equity firm fell below its June 21 offering price of $31. Investors have some nerve to dump Blackstone’s shares — don’t they know who Steve Schwarzman is?

articles.headline: 4 Held in Scottish Attack as British See Broader Plot
articles.snippet: Britain raised its terrorism threat alert to its highest level after two men crashed an S.U.V. into doors at Glasgow Airport and turned the vehicle into a fireball.
articles.abstract: Britain raised its terrorism threat alert to its highest level after two men crashed an S.U.V. into doors at Glasgow Airport and turned the vehicle into a fireball.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Sunday, July 1 — British officials raised the country’s terrorism threat alert to its highest level on Saturday after two men slammed an S.U.V. into entrance doors at Glasgow Airport and turned the vehicle into a potentially lethal fireball.
articles.byline: By Alan Cowell and Raymond Bonner

articles.headline: Companies in U.S. Increase Testing of Chinese Goods
articles.snippet: Widening recalls have forced big American companies to focus on potential hazards that were overlooked in the past.
articles.abstract: Widening recalls have forced big American companies to focus on potential hazards that were overlooked in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Mills, Kellogg, Toys “R” Us and other big American companies are increasing their scrutiny of thousands of everyday products they receive from Chinese suppliers, as widening recalls of items like toys and toothpaste force them to focus on potential hazards that were overlooked in the past.

articles.headline: Can She Turn Yahoo Into, Well, Google?
articles.snippet: Susan L. Decker, president of Yahoo, faces daunting challenges: rebuilding morale, attracting top-notch recruits and delivering better results for investors.
articles.abstract: Susan L. Decker, president of Yahoo, faces daunting challenges: rebuilding morale, attracting top-notch recruits and delivering better results for investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN early May, a little more than a month before she became president of Yahoo, Susan L. Decker found herself dining at Gorat’s Steak House in Omaha along with her husband and two of the restaurant’s most famous regulars: Warren E. Buffett and Bill Gates.

articles.headline: Perspective on Her Side, Mrs. Edwards Enters Fray
articles.snippet: Since her cancer diagnosis, Elizabeth Edwards has become an increasing presence in her husband’s campaign.
articles.abstract: Since her cancer diagnosis, Elizabeth Edwards has become an increasing presence in her husband’s campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 30  Three months after Elizabeth Edwards said that her cancer had returned in inoperable form, her role and influence in John Edwards’s presidential campaign is undiminished. She has made a flurry of charged public appearances, become a regular presence advising Mr. Edwards on the campaign trail, and wields behind-the-scenes influence in many internal campaign decisions, aides said.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Bomber’s End: Flash of Terror, Humble Grave
articles.snippet: In Afghanistan, suicide bombers are buried without ceremony, the forgettable end to an unforgivable act.
articles.abstract: In Afghanistan, suicide bombers are buried without ceremony, the forgettable end to an unforgivable act.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 30 — The two men had come to the common end of all human journeys. Their bodies, swathed in bloody white sheets, lay on a rocky hillside. Awaiting them were two thin rectangles of shallow graves. The city of Kabul was responsible for the burial. No mullah had been asked to preside over this earthly farewell.

articles.headline: Labels Lack Food’s Origin Despite Law
articles.snippet: Lobbyists and lawmakers have held off on enforcing a law requiring country-of-origin labels on meat and produce.
articles.abstract: Lobbyists and lawmakers have held off on enforcing a law requiring country-of-origin labels on meat and produce.
articles.lead_paragraph: In every American supermarket, labels tell shoppers where their seafood came from. But there are no such labels for meat, produce or nuts.

articles.headline: No Oil Yet, but African Isle Finds Slippery Dealings
articles.snippet: The tiny island nation of São Tomé may have attracted oil-related corruption without producing any oil.
articles.abstract: The tiny island nation of São Tomé may have attracted oil-related corruption without producing any oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: A decade ago, geologists found signs that one of Africa’s least-known countries, the tiny island nation of São Tomé and Principe, might hold a king’s ransom in oil.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: The Winding Road to a Giant Deal to Sell Bell Canada
articles.snippet: The 51.7 billion Canadian bid to take Bell Canada private unquestionably rewards the company’s shareholders. But getting there was not a pleasant experience for everyone.
articles.abstract: The 51.7 billion Canadian bid to take Bell Canada private unquestionably rewards the company’s shareholders. But getting there was not a pleasant experience for everyone.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, July 1 — The record-breaking 51.7 billion Canadian bid to take Bell Canada private unquestionably rewards the company’s shareholders. But getting there was not a pleasant experience for everyone.

articles.headline: In Hunt for Bomb Plotters, Britain Sees a Qaeda Link
articles.snippet: The police expanded their search for the plotters of the attempted attacks, arresting a fifth suspect. At least one of the detainees was said to be a physician.
articles.abstract: The police expanded their search for the plotters of the attempted attacks, arresting a fifth suspect. At least one of the detainees was said to be a physician.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Monday, July 2 — With their investigation moving at breakneck speed, the police expanded their hunt on Sunday for the plotters of attempted car bomb attacks in London and Glasgow that the British government called the work of terrorists linked to Al Qaeda. Officers raided homes in three cities and arrested another suspect, bringing the total to five, including at least one identified as a medical doctor.
articles.byline: By Alan Cowell and Raymond Bonner

articles.headline: Xbox Offers a Forum to Reach Gamers Where They Live
articles.snippet: Since November, Xbox LIVE Marketplace has offered video-on-demand downloads of movies and download-to-own episodes of television shows.
articles.abstract: Since November, Xbox LIVE Marketplace has offered video-on-demand downloads of movies and download-to-own episodes of television shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Josh Roberts got his first video game system — Atari — when he was 4, and since then, “I’ve had all the latest and greatest systems,” said Mr. Roberts, 27, an advertising account executive. The roster includes various versions of Nintendo, Sega and Sony PlayStation, the original Microsoft Xbox and now its latest iteration, Xbox 360.

articles.headline: Largely Alone, Pioneers Reclaim New Orleans
articles.snippet: Determined former residents who are bringing the Gentilly neighborhood back to life say government help has been minimal.
articles.abstract: Determined former residents who are bringing the Gentilly neighborhood back to life say government help has been minimal.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, July 1 — The sound of hammers and saws. New green grass. A few freshly painted facades. Birdsong piping from a young tree.

articles.headline: Rival Manufacturers Chasing the iPhone
articles.snippet: Asian manufacturers fear Apple may repeat in wireless communications what it accomplished in portable music with the iPod: changing the industry.
articles.abstract: Asian manufacturers fear Apple may repeat in wireless communications what it accomplished in portable music with the iPod: changing the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, June 29 — While Americans have been blitzed with news about the iPhone’s debut, many in South Korea’s and Japan’s technology industries initially greeted Apple’s flashy new handset with yawns.

articles.headline: A $135 Million Home, but if You Have to Ask ...
articles.snippet: Selling the most expensive single-family residential property on the U.S. market mostly consists of saying no.
articles.abstract: Selling the most expensive single-family residential property on the U.S. market mostly consists of saying no.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo. — Some brokers have to shout to sell real estate in a glutted market, or employ ever more tortured elocutions of spin. Joshua Saslove whispers.

articles.headline: As Senator Rose, Lobbying Became Family Affair
articles.snippet: Lobbying by Fred D. Thompson’s sons after their father won his Senate seat suggests how far the family has come.
articles.abstract: Lobbying by Fred D. Thompson’s sons after their father won his Senate seat suggests how far the family has come.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 29 — On Christmas Eve 1994, Fred D. Thompson Jr. was out of a job. A 34-year-old self-described late bloomer, Mr. Thompson had graduated from law school just two years before and practiced law only for his father, Fred D. Thompson Sr., who was about to be sworn in as a senator from Tennessee.

articles.headline: Universal in Dispute With Apple Over iTunes
articles.snippet: The Universal Music Group notified Apple that it will not renew its annual contract to sell music through iTunes.
articles.abstract: The Universal Music Group notified Apple that it will not renew its annual contract to sell music through iTunes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven P. Jobs, the co-founder and chief executive of Apple, is an emerging force in the mobile phone business, thanks to the snaking lines of gadget fans who queued up last week to buy the iPhone. But now he faces a headache in an industry Apple already dominates — digital music.

articles.headline: How the Grid Is Changing the Village
articles.snippet: A broader popular culture that many residents of Corinth, N.Y., have rejected by leaving big cities now rides back toward them on the information superhighway.
articles.abstract: A broader popular culture that many residents of Corinth, N.Y., have rejected by leaving big cities now rides back toward them on the information superhighway.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deborah Stollery apologized through the screen window of the ice cream stand she runs in Corinth, N.Y., for being in a bit of a tizzy.

articles.headline: Carlyle Group in Talks to Acquire Virgin Media
articles.snippet: The potential bid for Sir Richard Branson’s Virgin Media could be worth more than $20 billion.
articles.abstract: The potential bid for Sir Richard Branson’s Virgin Media could be worth more than $20 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group is in discussions with Virgin Media, the British cable company whose largest investor is Richard Branson, over a potential bid worth around $20 billion, a person familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Julia Werdigier
